mn61:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
mn61:2.1: Now at that time Venerable Rāhula was staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
mn61:2.2: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ambalaṭṭhika to see Venerable Rāhula.
mn61:2.3: Rāhula saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.
mn61:2.4: He spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.
mn61:2.5: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
mn61:2.7: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
mn61:3.1: Then the Buddha, leaving a little water in the pot, addressed Rāhula,
mn61:3.2: “Rāhula, do you see this little bit of water left in the pot?”
mn61:3.4: “That’s how little of the ascetic’s nature is left in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
mn61:4.1: Then the Buddha, tossing away what little water was left in the pot, said to Rāhula,
mn61:4.2: “Do you see this little bit of water that was tossed away?”
mn61:4.4: “That’s how the ascetic’s nature is tossed away in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
mn61:5.1: Then the Buddha, turning the pot upside down, said to Rāhula,
mn61:5.2: “Do you see how this pot is turned upside down?”
mn61:5.4: “That’s how the ascetic’s nature is turned upside down in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
mn61:6.1: Then the Buddha, turning the pot right side up, said to Rāhula,
mn61:6.2: “Do you see how this pot is vacant and hollow?”
mn61:6.4: “That’s how vacant and hollow the ascetic’s nature is in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.
mn61:7.1: Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. In battle it uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, but it still protects its trunk.
mn61:7.3: ‘This royal bull elephant still protects its trunk.
mn61:7.4: It has not yet given its life.’
mn61:7.5: But when that royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk, its rider thinks:
mn61:7.6: ‘This royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk.
mn61:7.8: Now there is nothing that royal bull elephant would not do.’
mn61:7.9: In the same way, when someone is not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie, there is no bad deed they would not do, I say.
mn61:7.10: So you should train like this: ‘I will not tell a lie, even for a joke.’
mn61:8.2: What is the purpose of a mirror?”
mn61:8.4: “In the same way, deeds of body, speech, and mind should be done only after repeated checking.
mn61:9.1: When you want to act with the body, you should check on that same deed:
mn61:9.2: ‘Does this act with the body that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both?
mn61:9.3: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
mn61:9.4: If, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:9.5: ‘This act with the body that I want to do leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:9.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ To the best of your ability, Rāhula, you should not do such a deed.
mn61:9.7: But if, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:9.8: ‘This act with the body that I want to do doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:9.9: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should do such a deed.
mn61:10.1: While you are acting with the body, you should check on that same act:
mn61:10.2: ‘Does this act with the body that I am doing lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both?
mn61:10.3: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
mn61:10.4: If, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:10.5: ‘This act with the body that I am doing leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:10.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should desist from such a deed.
mn61:10.7: But if, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:10.8: ‘This act with the body that I am doing doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:10.9: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should continue doing such a deed.
mn61:11.1: After you have acted with the body, you should check on that same act:
mn61:11.2: ‘Does this act with the body that I have done lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both?
mn61:11.3: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
mn61:11.4: If, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:11.5: ‘This act with the body that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:11.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
mn61:11.7: And having revealed it you should restrain yourself in future.
mn61:11.8: But if, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:11.9: ‘This act with the body that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:11.10: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, training day and night in skillful qualities.
mn61:12.1: When you want to act with speech, you should check on that same deed:
mn61:12.2: ‘Does this act of speech that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? …’ …
mn61:14.4: If, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:14.5: ‘This act of speech that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:14.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
mn61:14.7: And having revealed it you should restrain yourself in future.
mn61:14.8: But if, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:14.9: ‘This act of speech that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:14.10: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, training day and night in skillful qualities.
mn61:15.1: When you want to act with the mind, you should check on that same deed:
mn61:15.2: ‘Does this act of mind that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both? …’ …
mn61:17.4: If, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:17.5: ‘This act of mind that I have done leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:17.6: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should be horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that deed.
mn61:17.7: And being repelled, you should restrain yourself in future.
mn61:17.8: But if, while checking in this way, you know:
mn61:17.9: ‘This act with the mind that I have done doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
mn61:17.10: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should live in rapture and joy because of this, training day and night in skillful qualities.
mn61:18.1: All the ascetics and brahmins of the past, future, and present who purify their physical, verbal, and mental actions do so after repeatedly checking.
mn61:18.4: So Rāhula, you should train yourself like this: ‘I will purify my physical, verbal, and mental actions after repeatedly checking.’”
mn61:18.6: That is what the Buddha said.
mn61:18.7: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula approved what the Buddha said.
